urn:contentItem:6G3J-VS63-RTM6-90D2-00000-00The next big wildfires are coming - but Ontario doesn't have nearly enough firefighters2025-06-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:54ZLexisNexisNEWS/ONTARIOPg. 1The next big wildfires are coming - but Ontario doesn't have nearly enough firefightersMarco Chown Oved

A small forest fire had broken out on the edge of town and quickly grown into a towering inferno, forcing an evacuation of the small fly-in community of Deer Lake, Ont.

For four days at the end of May, small propeller planes flew more than 900 people out of town - and they were lucky to even get into the air.

Burning trees had surrounded the airport for a day and a half, grounding all aircraft, and community leaders such as David Meekis had been lining up fishing boats to ferry people across the lake in case the fire entered town.

"We were just looking for any means (of escape) possible, planning for the worst," he said. "I was just getting the message out: Can you have your boat ready?"

Meekis went outside to check on his 16-foot fishing boat hitched to his truck. He figured if it came to it, he could put 10 people in the boat and his small 40-horsepower motor would get them across the lake in about 10 minutes. Then he'd come back and do it again and again until everyone was safe.

"I had fuel. I had my oars. I even had my fishing rods ready and stuff. It was all set up and ready to go," he said.

Fortunately, a water bomber was on the scene within hours, arriving when the fire was aggressively spreading, going from two to 200 hectares in only an hour and a half, Meekis said. Dropping more than 6,000 litres of water in a single load, the "super scooper" was able to cool down the area around the airport enough so that ground crews could beat back the flames and the runway was reopened.

With more than 40 Ontario fire rangers on the ground deploying hoses and sprinklers, the town's essential infrastructure has been saved. At one point, the fire was raging less than 100 metres from the nursing station; the band office came within 60 metres of going up in smoke.

The people of Deer Lake are still worried about the fire, which had burned more than 17,000 hectares when Meekis got on that plane in early June and has since exploded to over 183,000 hectares. If it flares back up around town, it could destroy their homes. But after witnessing Ontario's forest fire fighters in action, Meekis was hopeful they have escaped the worst.

"They're good people who have been through this before and are very knowledgeable and know how to fight the fire. I'm grateful there's people like that."

But with this new breed of fire, "we're going to need a lot more of them," he said.

'It's just not a livable job anymore'It's hard to predict how bad a fire season will be because the weather can turn on a dime. But this year in Ontario is shaping up to be a doozy.

The wildfire that forced the evacuation of Deer Lake - dubbed Red Lake 12 - is alone more than twice as large as all the forest fires that burned last year, provincewide.

Ontario doesn't have enough wilderness firefighters. I learned what it takes to be one

And while the town is safe for now, and everyone has been safely evacuated, some people are questioning how the fire got so out of hand so quickly - and whether that would have happened if there were more fire rangers available.

Ten years ago, there were 732 fire rangers. Now there are 630.

At a time when the threat of forest fires is greater than it has ever been, our front line of defence is understaffed by more than 100 firefighters.

And with fewer fire rangers, reaction time to new fires is slower, and more of them are escaping containment.

"Would these fires have become as big as they are if we just had the same resources as we've had in the past?" said Noah Freedman, a crew leader and vice-president of the fire rangers' union, OPSEU Local 703.

The problem, according to government reports, the union as well as more than a dozen interviews with current and former firefighters, is staff retention. What used to be a career for people across Ontario's North has turned into a summer job for most.

The Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch (AFFES) "is losing their experienced staff at an alarming rate," states an internal Ministry of Natural Resources report, obtained by the Star.

The report, published nearly a decade ago, identified a turnover rate of 45 per cent - a rate which has not improved.

"Because of this turnover, the organization has been forced to promote employees despite them possessing only minimal practical experience and limited fire line expertise," the report states.

It's not just fire rangers that are short-staffed. At least three of the province's nine waterbombers have been grounded this season due to a lack of pilots, according to OPSEU.

"Just weeks ago, crews in Northwestern Ontario worked tirelessly battling wildfires to save people's homes and property," the union said in a statement. "All the while, an aircraft sat unused, calling into question whether that grounded aircraft and a skilled crew could have made a difference."

In a dangerous job like forest firefighting, a lack of experience can be deadly.

"Say you have a guy that has 10 years of experience leading a crew. They can see things and read things that somebody who has become a crew leader after three years just won't notice or won't even think of," said Dean Rosen, a former Ontario fire ranger who worked for five seasons out of Pickle Lake, more than 500 kilometres north of Thunder Bay. "Lots of those little mistakes can have big consequences when you just don't have the right amount of experience."

Rosen, who wrote his master's thesis in 2021 on turnover in the Ontario FireRanger program, says there are many issues affecting retention, ranging from the remote, isolated work conditions to the physical difficulty and danger of the work itself. The fact that forest firefighters aren't employed year-round means that everyone is effectively laid off every year and has months to think about whether they want to go back.

But ultimately, it comes down to pay.

While entry-level pay recently went up to $25.38 an hour, it hasn't kept up with inflation. Today, crew members are only making one-and-a-half times minimum wage. Fifteen years ago, their wages were more than double minimum wage.

"It's just not a livable job anymore, really. Unless fire seasons are crazy and you're working your ass off," said Rosen. "Because the money's in the overtime."

In 2021, the last big wildfire season in Ontario, Rosen said fire rangers were able to work 500 hours overtime, adding 50 per cent to their take-home earnings.

In the quiet seasons since, there hasn't been much action. Not only is this discouraging people from returning, those who do are not building up much on-the-ground experience.

"You get somebody who comes into the program and they're all excited and amped up and ready to go, and then they're just kind of sitting all summer. And that really deters them from coming back the next year," he said. "If you're not giving them incentive to stay in the program and to develop their skills and experience and move up the ranks, why would they?"

The budget is not enough - even in slow yearsThe bottleneck is a lack of crew leaders. No matter how many rookies are brought in, the province cannot hire additional crew members if there are no crew leaders to supervise them.

According to a 2024 ministerial briefing document obtained by the Star, the optimal number of fire rangers is 756, organized into 189 four-person crews. But in order to achieve this level of coverage, the province needs 189 crew leaders - and it has been coming up far short.

This year, there are only 144 crew leaders and, as a result, the FireRangers are limited to fielding that number of crews. Even though one-third of these crews were assigned an extra member - adopting a five-person model that had been discontinued years ago after it was found to be inefficient - the province is still 45 crews and more than 100 fire rangers short.

With fewer people on the front line, the FireRangers' response time is suffering. Over the past 10 years, the province's preferred performance metric, called "wildfire containment effectiveness" or "initial attack success rate," has dropped markedly.

The percentage of significant fires that were "being held" by noon the day after they were reported was nearly 98 per cent in 2014. In 2022, the most recent year for which numbers are available, that had dropped to 92 per cent - well short of the 96 per cent target.

They say Muskoka won't burn. But climate has changed the calculus

Getting to a fire quickly is important because only two per cent of fires account for 98 per cent of the forest area burned each year, according to a Ministry of Natural Resources presentation prepared for the Auditor General and obtained by the Star. In other words, 98 per cent of fires are put out when they're small and it's the handful of fires that escape early containment that cause virtually all the damage.

In Deer Lake, so many resources were focused on saving the town that the fire was never contained and it grew rapidly in the opposite direction. A week later, it had become the second biggest fire on record in Ontario, and had burned 60 km north until it reached the doorstep of next town, Sandy Lake, which also had to be evacuated.

With more fires and fewer fire rangers to fight them, the pressure on the small number of experienced leaders increases.

Ten years ago, according to the ministry report on recruitment and retention, more than half the crew leaders had one year of experience or less in the position, and the vast majority of the initial attacks on fires were led by the more experienced crew leaders. At the fire base in Sioux Lookout, for example, only one of the 17 crew leaders had led more than 10 initial attacks, and he had 48 to his name.

While the AFFES has produced two follow up reports over the last decade, it declined to provide them to the Star. The Ministry of Natural Resources and Forests did not respond to questions for this story, instead sending a statement that read: "Ontario remains an internationally recognized leader in wildfire fire management."

Over the last two years, the province has added 100 year-round "support" positions, and paid out a one-time "retention incentive payment" of up to $5,000 to fire rangers last year, the statement read. There's also been a pay bump, a bonus introduced for days spent camping while fighting fires and as much as $500 in reimbursement for eligible expenses related to training, including the cost of safety boots.

At the FireRangers base in Haliburton, supervisor Bob Hurley said the real difference maker has been the introduction of nine-month "tech" contracts for crew leaders, which allows some of them to start earlier in the spring and stay later in the fall.

"I think we've turned the corner. We're starting to see the positive recruitment come back in, and we're starting to see people come back. They want to be here," he said.

According to the union that represents fire rangers, however, these retention measures haven't been enough to address the problem.

"We are having an enormously difficult time keeping people because the job is extremely demanding and we aren't being recognized in terms of compensation for how hard we work and the risk that we put on ourselves in the same way that structural firefighters are," said Freedman, who has nine years of front-line experience.

It's not just a question of the number of rangers, he said, but a lack of crews means they can fight fewer fires at once, take longer to respond to new fires, and run the risk of letting them grow out of control.

"They only have seven crews in Red Lake, when they're supposed to have 15. In Geraldton, they've got six crews, and they're supposed to have 18," he said. "It's bad."

While Ontario's emergency wildfire suppression budget has nearly doubled over the past 10 years, the cost of actually fighting the fires is almost always more - a lot more. The AFFES has blown past its budget every year but one over the past decade. It happens in big fire years as expected, but also in quiet years, when little forest burns.

Asked about these budget overruns, Ministry of Natural Resources spokesperson Mike Fenn explained that the budget "ensures the resources are in place to respond immediately at the onset of fire season."

"Once the total costs for the fire season can be accurately predicted, the Ministry will request the balance of the total funding requirements from the contingency fund," he said.

This is not a good way to plan, Freedman said, because it leaves fire rangers scrambling to find helicopters and planes in the middle of a busy fire season instead of leasing them in advance. The approach is indicative of a service stretched to its limits, one that scrambles to fulfil its duties with fewer staff and aircraft than needed, he added.

"We are not anywhere near what they call the 'ideal capacity,' and that's saying nothing about the capacity we'll need in the future," said Freedman.

The number of fires and forest area burned across Canada, which has doubled over the past 60 years, is projected to double again by the end of this century. It stands to reason that the cost of forest fire fighting will also rise, but by how much remains the focus of debate.

Studies have pegged the rise as low as 45 per cent and as high as 145 per cent.

Research carried out by the Canadian Forest Service found that in order to adequately contain the bigger fires and prevent them from entering towns and cities, the cost could be far greater. The study found a 15 per cent increase in the number and size of forest fires would require a doubling of resources needed to contain them at the same rate as today.

So if fire activity doubles as expected, Ontario would need six times more firefighting resources - fire rangers, water bombers, helicopters and support staff - or risk losing control of many more massive runaway fires.

How to prepare for the next fire disasterIf you want to see a vision of a future wracked by climate change, you need only look across the country to British Columbia.

Over the past 10 years, Canada's westernmost province has suffered repeated natural disasters: wildfires that have levelled towns, torrential rains that have washed out highways, floods that have turned entire communities into islands and heatwaves that have killed hundreds.

The provincial government has spent a lot of time reviewing the damage and preparing for the next disaster and the ways it has beefed up its wildfire service are instructive for Ontario.

Despite having a smaller land mass to cover and having fewer people to protect, B.C. now employs twice as many wildfire fighters as Ontario. It also has three times as many waterbombers and more helicopters.

In 2022, B.C. announced it would convert the service from seasonal to year-round, pledging more than $200 million in new funding. In the three years since, the number of year-round jobs has risen by 56 per cent, according to figures provided to the Star, and BCWS now employs more than 600 year-round staff - nearly the same number of people as the entire fire ranger force in Ontario.

"Historically, wildfires were really seen as just like a summer situation. The core wildfire season would be July and August and that was what we were prepared for," said BC Wildfire Service Information Officer Sarah Budd. "This is a year-round problem. The climate that we're working in is changing, and we need to be ready for a much longer response season."

Not only are the forest fire fighters in B.C. on the ground earlier in the spring and staying later in the fall, but many of them are now involved in risk-reduction activities in the winter, in hopes of improving the next season's response.

This means doing more prescribed burns that consume fuel on the forest floor that would otherwise feed summer fires. It also means improving access roads to get fire crews into high-risk areas, proactively creating firebreaks with heavy equipment in the winter when the machines won't bog down, and working with nearby communities to develop partnerships with local fire departments and emergency evacuation plans.

While Ontario's response mirrors some of these initiatives, it falls short of the massive effort underway in B.C. If the predictions of bigger fire seasons are to be believed, and the erosion of the fire rangers' ranks is to be turned around, a fully year-round service is the formula B.C. considers best.

"There's been a pretty intense focus on the human resources side of it, making this into a place where people can build a career, so that you can come up through the crews and then continue to contribute that expertise. That way, we're not losing that knowledge when people peel off year after year," said Budd.

This story is Part 1 in The Coming Firestorm, a three-part series on the growing risk of wildfires fuelled by human-induced climate change.

In Part 2: A Star reporter learns to be an Ontario fire ranger - the province's front line against the next uncontrollable blaze.

Coming Monday in Part 3: Why computer models are failing to predict "impossible" wildfires, and what that means for Southern Ontario.

They can see things and read things that somebody who has become a crew leader after three years just won't notice or won't even think of," said Dean Rosen, a former Ontario fire ranger who worked for five seasons out of Pickle Lake, more than 500 kilometres north of Thunder Bay. Rosen, who wrote his master's thesis in 2021 on turnover in the Ontario FireRanger program, says there are many issues affecting retention, ranging from the remote, isolated work conditions to the physical difficulty and danger of the work itself. The fact that forest firefighters aren't employed year-round means that everyone is effectively laid off every year and has months to think about whether they want to go back.

But ultimately, it comes down to pay.

While entry-level pay recently went up to $25.38 an hour, it hasn't kept up with inflation. Today, crew members are only making one-and-a-half times minimum wage. Fifteen years ago, their wages were more than double minimum wage.

"It's just not a livable job anymore, really. Unless fire seasons are crazy and you're working your ass off," said Rosen. "Because the money's in the overtime."

In the quiet seasons since, there hasn't been much action. Not only is this discouraging people from returning, those who do are not building up much on-the-ground experience.

"You get somebody who comes into the program and they're all excited and amped up and ready to go, and then they're just kind of sitting all summer. And that really deters them from coming back the next year," he said. "If you're not giving them incentive to stay in the program and to develop their skills and experience and move up the ranks, why would they?"

According to a 2024 ministerial briefing document obtained by the Star, the optimal number of fire rangers is 756, organized into 189 four-person crews. But in order to achieve this level of coverage, the province needs 189 crew leaders - and it has been coming up far short.

This year, there are only 144 crew leaders and, as a result, the FireRangers are limited to fielding that number of crews. Even though one-third of these crews were assigned an extra member - adopting a five-person model that had been discontinued years ago after it was found to be inefficient - the province is still 45 crews and more than 100 fire rangers short.

With fewer people on the front line, the FireRangers' response time is suffering. Over the past 10 years, the province's preferred performance metric, called "wildfire containment effectiveness" or "initial attack success rate," has dropped markedly.

The percentage of significant fires that were "being held" by noon the day after they were reported was nearly 98 per cent in 2014. In 2022, the most recent year for which numbers are available, that had dropped to 92 per cent - well short of the 96 per cent target.

Getting to a fire quickly is important because only two per cent of fires account for 98 per cent of the forest area burned each year, according to a Ministry of Natural Resources presentation prepared for the Auditor General and obtained by the Star. In other words, 98 per cent of fires are put out when they're small and it's the handful of fires that escape early containment that cause virtually all the damage.

In Deer Lake, so many resources were focused on saving the town that the fire was never contained and it grew rapidly in the opposite direction. A week later, it had become the second biggest fire on record in Ontario, and had burned 60 km north until it reached the doorstep of next town, Sandy Lake, which also had to be evacuated.

Ten years ago, according to the ministry report on recruitment and retention, more than half the crew leaders had one year of experience or less in the position, and the vast majority of the initial attacks on fires were led by the more experienced crew leaders. At the fire base in Sioux Lookout, for example, only one of the 17 crew leaders had led more than 10 initial attacks, and he had 48 to his name.

While the AFFES has produced two follow up reports over the last decade, it declined to provide them to the Star. The Ministry of Natural Resources and Forests did not respond to questions for this story, instead sending a statement that read: "Ontario remains an internationally recognized leader in wildfire fire management."

Over the last two years, the province has added 100 year-round "support" positions, and paid out a one-time "retention incentive payment" of up to $5,000 to fire rangers last year, the statement read. There's also been a pay bump, a bonus introduced for days spent camping while fighting fires and as much as $500 in reimbursement for eligible expenses related to training, including the cost of safety boots.

At the FireRangers base in Haliburton, supervisor Bob Hurley said the real difference maker has been the introduction of nine-month "tech" contracts for crew leaders, which allows some of them to start earlier in the spring and stay later in the fall.

"I think we've turned the corner. We're starting to see the positive recruitment come back in, and we're starting to see people come back. They want to be here," he said.

According to the union that represents fire rangers, however, these retention measures haven't been enough to address the problem.

urn:contentItem:6FYY-K2B3-RTFD-W19R-00000-00Insurance experts available to help Saskatchewan residents affected by wildfire2025-06-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:54ZLexisNexisInsurance experts available to help Saskatchewan residents affected by wildfire

Insurance Bureau of Canada offershelpline for affected residents

EDMONTON, AB, June 5, 2025 /CNW/ - Due to out-of-control wildfires in Saskatchewan, which have forced the evacuation of approximately 15,000 residents and prompted a provincewide state of emergency, Insurance Bureau of Canada (IBC) has deployed its Virtual Community Assistance Mobile Pavilion (V-CAMP) to provide insurance information to affected residents.

Prolonged dry and warm conditions across much of the province have led to volatile fire conditions across northern Saskatchewan, with numerous large fires burning. Several large 'fires of note' have prompted evacuations of more than two dozen northern communities. Some homes, businesses, and cabins have been reported damaged or destroyed.

"Our hearts go out to the individuals and families whose lives have been disrupted by these fires and who have lost property," said Aaron Sutherland, Vice-President, Pacific and Western, IBC. "We applaud all the first responders who have been working tirelessly to protect the affected communities. Rest assured that anyone whose property was damaged can contact their insurance representative when they are ready to start the claims process. Saskatchewan's home and business insurers are committed to protecting your tomorrow, by standing with you today."

IBC is in close contact with provincial government and emergency management officials, as well as with municipal officials in the affected communities. This situation is changing rapidly.

Insurers serve as "second responders" in the recovery period after catastrophe strikes. IBC's V-CAMP is staffed with trained insurance industry personnel at IBC's Consumer Information Centre at 1-844-2ask-IBC (1-844-227-5422) and AskIBCWest@ibc.cato help address consumers' general questions about their home, business or vehicle insurance policies. This includes questions about Additional Living Expenses for those who have been evacuated. Affected residents can also visit IBC's Wildfires & Insurance webpage to learn more about insurance and the various stages of the claims process.

Information about the current forest fire danger, forest fire activity and fire restrictions across the province can be found on theGovernment of Saskatchewan's Emergenciesand Response webpage.

When the Smoke Clears . . . What's Covered?

Home insurance policies cover damage caused by fire, even if the fire began on a neighbouring property, as long as the fire was not started intentionally by the policy holder.All standard home insurance policies cover additional living expenses (ALE). If you've been ordered by a civil or provincial authority to leave your home, keep the receipts for your living expenses (for example, hotel costs). Most homeowner's and tenant's insurance policies cover any reasonable additional living expenses for a specified period of time. Ask your insurance representative about the amount of living expenses you're entitled to claim.

Tips for Starting the Claims Process

Home insurance policies cover damage caused by fire, even if the fire began on a neighbouring property, as long as the fire was not started intentionally by the policy holder.All standard home insurance policies cover additional living expenses (ALE). If you've been ordered by a civil or provincial authority to leave your home, keep the receipts for your living expenses (for example, hotel costs). Most homeowner's and tenant's insurance policies cover any reasonable additional living expenses for a specified period of time. Ask your insurance representative about the amount of living expenses you're entitled to claim.

Seasonal or secondary residences

When it is safe to do so, check any seasonal or secondary residences (e.g., cottages) and report any damage to your insurance representative as soon as possible. Policies for these properties may have different coverage or limits than a primary home insurance policy. Review your policy or check with your insurance professional to confirm your coverage.

About Insurance Bureau of Canada

Established in 1964, Insurance Bureau of Canada (IBC) is the national industry association representing Canada's private home, auto and business insurers. Its member companies make up the vast majority of Canada's highly competitive property and casualty (P&C) insurance market.

As the leading advocate for Canada's private P&C insurers, IBC collaborates with governments, regulators and stakeholders to support a competitive environment for the P&C insurance industry to continue to help protect Canadians from the risks of today and tomorrow.

IBC believes that Canadians value and deserve a responsive and resilient private P&C insurance industry that provides insurance solutions to both individuals and businesses.

For media releases, IN Focus articles, or to book an interview with an IBC representative, visit ibc.ca. Follow us on LinkedIn, X and Instagram, and like us on Facebook. If you have a question about home, auto or business insurance, contact IBC's Consumer Information Centre at 1-844-2ask-IBC. We're here to help.

Studies have pegged the rise as low as 45 per cent and as high as 145 per cent.

Research carried out by the Canadian Forest Service found that in order to adequately contain the bigger fires and prevent them from entering towns and cities, the cost could be far greater. The study found a 15 per cent increase in the number and size of forest fires would require a doubling of resources needed to contain them at the same rate as today.

So if fire activity doubles as expected, Ontario would need six times more firefighting resources - fire rangers, water bombers, helicopters and support staff - or risk losing control of many more massive runaway fires.

How to prepare for the next fire disasterIf you want to see a vision of a future wracked by climate change, you need only look across the country to British Columbia.

Over the past 10 years, Canada's westernmost province has suffered repeated natural disasters: wildfires that have levelled towns, torrential rains that have washed out highways, floods that have turned entire communities into islands and heatwaves that have killed hundreds.

The provincial government has spent a lot of time reviewing the damage and preparing for the next disaster and the ways it has beefed up its wildfire service are instructive for Ontario.

Despite having a smaller land mass to cover and having fewer people to protect, B.C. now employs twice as many wildfire fighters as Ontario. It also has three times as many waterbombers and more helicopters.

In 2022, B.C. announced it would convert the service from seasonal to year-round, pledging more than $200 million in new funding. In the three years since, the number of year-round jobs has risen by 56 per cent, according to figures provided to the Star, and BCWS now employs more than 600 year-round staff - nearly the same number of people as the entire fire ranger force in Ontario.

"Historically, wildfires were really seen as just like a summer situation. The core wildfire season would be July and August and that was what we were prepared for," said BC Wildfire Service Information Officer Sarah Budd. "This is a year-round problem. The climate that we're working in is changing, and we need to be ready for a much longer response season."

Not only are the forest fire fighters in B.C. on the ground earlier in the spring and staying later in the fall, but many of them are now involved in risk-reduction activities in the winter, in hopes of improving the next season's response.

This means doing more prescribed burns that consume fuel on the forest floor that would otherwise feed summer fires. It also means improving access roads to get fire crews into high-risk areas, proactively creating firebreaks with heavy equipment in the winter when the machines won't bog down, and working with nearby communities to develop partnerships with local fire departments and emergency evacuation plans.

While Ontario's response mirrors some of these initiatives, it falls short of the massive effort underway in B.C. If the predictions of bigger fire seasons are to be believed, and the erosion of the fire rangers' ranks is to be turned around, a fully year-round service is the formula B.C. considers best.

"There's been a pretty intense focus on the human resources side of it, making this into a place where people can build a career, so that you can come up through the crews and then continue to contribute that expertise. That way, we're not losing that knowledge when people peel off year after year," said Budd.

This story is Part 1 in The Coming Firestorm, a three-part series on the growing risk of wildfires fuelled by human-induced climate change.

In Part 2: A Star reporter learns to be an Ontario fire ranger - the province's front line against the next uncontrollable blaze.

Coming Monday in Part 3: Why computer models are failing to predict "impossible" wildfires, and what that means for Southern Ontario.

B9Focus on 'the unimaginable'Digital models need a new approach to predict wildfiresRebecca Gao Rebecca Gao writes about technology for MaRS. Torstar, the parent company of the Toronto Star, has partnered with MaRS to highlight innovation in Canadian companies.

As wildfires raged in northern Ontario last month, the effects were felt throughout the province. Those in areas close to the blazes were evacuated. As far south as Chatham, residents were advised to avoid unnecessary outdoor activities. In Toronto, besieged by a brutal heat wave, the urban heat island effect trapped pollutants in the densely packed city, resulting in the dubious honour of being named one of the cities with the worst air quality in the world.

Although authorities have become accustomed to taking action during wildfire season, the increasing intensity, duration and scope of fires mean that their impact is felt in areas that used to be impervious to forest fire fallout, and pre-existing protocols no longer suffice. While organizations and various levels of government conduct drills to help manage emergency situations, there are limits to how effective real-life practice can be if one is facing a previously unheard-of scenario.

"That's where computer modelling comes in," says Myrna Bittner, the CEO and co-founder of RunWithIt Synthetics, which has developed an AI-driven platform (she describes it as Google Earth meets Sim City) that can help municipalities and other groups visualize how a particular crisis might play out depending on different variables.

Virtual models and algorithmic calculations have long been involved in emergency planning, but as climate change makes it harder to anticipate the parameters of wildfires and other natural disasters, old frameworks are no longer effective.

"The failure is in the unimaginable," says Bittner, who notes that conventional climate modelling has often focused on incremental shifts over time. What's missing from that approach, she says, are "the sudden and severe and chronic and compounding disasters" that people need to understand in order to protect themselves and their communities.

For RunWithIt, Bittner uses visualizations and leverages population-specific data that allows her to represent, for instance, how people navigate daily life in their community, how many homes will be permeated by smoke and how many residents will experience health complications.

Rather than foregrounding the human experience, many predictive tools focus on infrastructure destruction, buildings lost, acreage burnt. This makes it harder for people to grasp the urgency of a potential disaster - and it speaks to how virtual modelling itself needs to evolve. The world is not fixed or binary, Bittner says.

"We need to be constantly revising and augmenting our understanding," she adds, "and the modelling world needs to escape that foundation of being reliant on historical data, because the future is not like the past."

Manzil expands banking options

for Muslim Americans

Toronto-based Manzil, which specializes in financial services that adhere to the core tenets of the Islamic faith, is a unique fintech resource for a group that can struggle to access inclusive banking options. The startup, which has been providing halal mortgages to Canadians since 2020 (Sharia law prohibits transactions that earn interest, so conventional mortgages are verboten), has just launched Manzil Invest USA, an app that will allow American customers to explore different investment options without compromising their religious beliefs.

X CEO is now ex-CEO

Linda Yaccarino, who was named CEO of X (formerly Twitter) two years ago, is exiting her role at the corporation. While things have been tumultuous throughout her tenure at the contentious social-media platform, Yaccarino's departure does come on the heels of a string of particularly egregious antisemitic posts by Grok, X's in-house AI bot - though she did not mention Grok in her parting statement.

Union news for NextStar

Workers at the NextStar Energy plant in Windsor, Ont., Canada's first large-scale electric vehicle (EV) battery cell manufacturing facility, have voted to ratify their first collective agreement. According to Unifor Local 444, 88 per cent of employees were in favour of the terms of the one-year deal, which includes a five per cent wage increase and improvements related to pensions, disability programs and workplace health and safety measures.

Nvidia's chips are back on China's table

California-based tech corporation Nvidia (which recently hit a market milestone) has been given the green light to resume selling AI chips to China. Nvidia had paused semiconductor trade with China in April due to the U.S. government's licensing requirements on Chinese orders.

According to U.S.Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, the government's decision is related to its negotiations with Beijing over rare earth metals - and, he says, because Nvidia's H20 chip is just the company's "fourth-best" model, the administration is not overly concerned about exporting it to China.

Cheelcare rolls onto the TSX

Richmond Hill-based Cheelcare, which specializes in innovative assistive tech, completed the final steps to become a publicly traded company on the Toronto Stock Exchange, where it's now listed as CHER. As of July 16, those interested in the startup's outside-the-box mobility solutions (which include rear-view cams, multidirectional tilt capabilities and power boosts for manual wheelchairs) can buy Cheelcare shares (Cheelshares?).

urn:contentItem:6GB5-VNN3-RSV2-92SJ-00000-00A look at megafires as an Oregon wildfire approaches the 100,000-acre mark2025-07-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:54ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONALA look at megafires as an Oregon wildfire approaches the 100,000-acre markIsabella O'malley And Sarah BrumfieldThe Associated Press

A wildfire burning in a sparsely populated region of central Oregon has become the largest fire this year and is on the verge of surpassing 100,000 acres to become what's officially known as a megafire.

Nearly 900 personnel have been battling the Cram Fire about 100 miles (160 kilometers) southeast of Portland, and they have it about 73% contained with more than 95,000 acres burned.

Here's a look at what megafires are and their increasing frequency in the warming world.

What is a megafire?

A megafire is generally defined as a fire that burns at least 100,000 acres, said Craig Clements, a climate scientist and director of the Wildfire Interdisciplinary Research Center at San Jose State University. That translates to about 156 square miles (404 square kilometers), or about half the size of New York City, which has a land area of 300 square miles (778 square kilometers).

Not all researchers agree that megafire is a scientifically sound term, though Clements has used it, and with its usage by the media increasing, he believes it’s “here to stay,” similar to “heat dome” and other popular weather labels that aren’t formal scientific terms. References to 100,000 acres as megafires can also be found in some government reports and research in recent years.

Are megafires happening more often?

There were at least 14 wildfires that burned more than 100,000 acres in the U.S. in 2024, according to a report by the National Interagency Coordination Center. A 2022 Interior Department report found that the number of megafires, which it defined as more than 100,000 acres, had increased in the preceding decade.

The amount of forest area burned each year in the western U.S. has approximately tripled since the 1980s, according to Brian Harvey, professor of forest fire science at the University of Washington.

The link between wildfires and climate change

The link between climate change and the increasing frequency of severe wildfires is particularly noticeable in the western U.S. and the boreal forest that stretches from Canada into Alaska, Harvey said, because these fire-prone ecosystems rely on winter snowpack to provide moisture all summer, and global warming has led to less snow, melting earlier in the year.

Wildfires naturally occur in healthy ecosystems, but extreme wildfires can slow the regrowth of native plants and trees and create favorable conditions for invasive species. The threat is growing as climate change can make wildfires more frequent and severe, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

Wildfire seasons are also influenced by lightning, land management practices and human-caused fires. Fires started by humans account for 70-90% of wildfires depending on the state and year, according to the USDA. This includes fires started by fireworks or discarded cigarettes.

Rising temperatures and longer droughts have dried out plants and leaves, driving wildfires in the western U.S. over the past 20 years, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. “Fires are getting bigger and this has been linked to drying of fuels from a warming climate,” Clements said.

“Large fires are, by definition, fires that are driven by extreme weather conditions like really high temperatures, low relative humidity and strong winds,” said James Johnston, assistant research professor at the University of Oregon. Climate change explains much of this weather, which is increasing the frequency of large, fast-moving fires, he added.

When and how did the Cram Fire start?

Firefighters responded to a fire burning on private land along U.S. Route 97 in the Willowdale area on July 13, according to Central Oregon Fire Information. It burned just over 2 square miles (6 square kilometers) at the time and was uncontained.

By the next day, it had grown so much that Gov. Tina Kotek invoked the Emergency Conflagration Act after county officials requested assistance, allowing the Oregon State Fire Marshal to mobilize resources to support local agencies. It was the sixth time this wildfire season that the governor invoked the act.

The cause is under investigation.

What kind of damage has it caused?

The fire has destroyed two homes and 14 outbuildings such as barns, pump houses, workshops or sheds, officials said. The threat to structures was significantly reduced when containment reached 73%, officials said Monday. Some evacuations remained in effect Monday, but some zones have been downgraded.

O’Malley reported from Philadelphia and Brumfield reported from Cockeysville, Maryland.

urn:contentItem:6FYF-JBB3-RW7H-S10N-00000-00Yukon wildfire fighters battle blazes across the prairies2025-06-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:54ZLexisNexisNATURAL DISASTERS NEWSYukon wildfire fighters battle blazes across the prairies

Yukon wildfire fighters are off to Alberta and Saskatchewan to help fight a major wildfire outbreak. 

"We've got a low fire danger rating here" said Haley Ritchie, an information officer with Yukon Wildland Fire. "So it's a good time for us to be able to help out." 

Both provinces have seen massive evacuations due to wildfires and a number of rural communities have also declared states of emergency. 

Five attack crews and an agency representative went to Alberta. The 21 people are accompanied by an L188 Electra heavy air tanker for aerial firefighting, along with the plane's two pilots and a dedicated mechanic. 

"They're such specialized aircraft that they come with their own personnel, who travel with the plane," said Ritchie.  

She said Yukon Wildfland Fire does not own the air tanker, but contracts it out for the season. 

A spokesperson for the Alberta government said  Yukon crews are battling the Swan complex fire near Slave Lake. It's the hardest hit part of Alberta, where more than 88,000 hectares have already burned. 

The Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre puts out the request for wildfire fighters, Ritchie said. Once they arrive within the province or territory, the local agency coordinates who goes where. 

Meanwhile, a division supervisor and trainee from the Yukon are also on their way to Saskatchewan to help out with personnel logistics there. 

"Hopefully in the future, we'll be able to get support when we need it too," said Ritchie. 

She said if the fire situation were to change in the Yukon, crews could be pulled back within 24 hours. A cool and damp spring has meant a slow start to wildfire season in the Yukon, where just four hectares have burned so far.

Personnel are allowed to be deployed for 19 days in total, including travel time.

urn:contentItem:6GCF-NRP3-RSMS-10FX-00000-00Preparing for the worst – Cree firefighters work on readiness during uneventful summer2025-07-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:54ZLexisNexisSPARE NEWSPreparing for the worst – Cree firefighters work on readiness during uneventful summerPatrick Quinn, Local Journalism Initiative ReporterThe Nation

While Cree leaders are relieved that the region has so far been largely spared from wildfires this summer, Western Canada hasn’t been so lucky. Heavy smoke from fires in the prairie provinces has drifted into Eeyou Istchee, causing occasional health advisories.

Waswanipi’s public safety department issued a smoke advisory July 13. With hazy conditions impacting air quality and visibility, community members were advised to limit time outdoors, keep windows and doors closed, and use air purifiers or air conditioning on recirculate mode. 

“The Cree Health Board monitors the air quality through Purple Air [sensors] set up in each community,” explained regional fire coordinator Lee-Roy Blacksmith. “They started installing community air quality devices in 2023 due to asthma, Elders and infants.”

These sensors send air quality data to a centralized map, which displays an Air Quality Health Index to determine the extent of health risk. The record-breaking 2023 wildfire season impacted over 11% of the land and nearly 60% of traplines throughout Eeyou Istchee, destroying 150 bush cabins and forcing numerous community evacuations.

With the resources of provincial forest firefighting agency SOPFEU overwhelmed by that year’s unprecedented damage, many people were upset that certain areas weren’t considered priorities for intervention. Firefighters in Eastmain had wanted to battle an approaching blaze but were advised not to by SOPFEU, resulting in the community being evacuated.

Quebec responded by investing $29 million in SOPFEU over five years, for a hiring blitz, new equipment and prevention initiatives. SOPFEU is also working with the Cree Nation to train additional firefighters in all Cree communities. 

“We have eight new forest firefighters doing our training right now and possibly four others who are getting recertified,” said Clarence Jason Jolly, Nemaska’s director of public health and safety. “They’re out there working on the fire pumps – I’d say we’re well prepared.”

Jolly said their department is able to fight fires up to 30 km from the community, as long as SOPFEU is informed and sufficient resources are available. SOPFEU will intervene with water bombers within this radius or if they threaten “priority infrastructure” like the nearby Hydro-Québec substation.

Situated beside a lake with a river behind the community, Nemaska has not installed further protections like a fire break. However, two of these strips of land cleared of combustible vegetation were built near Old Nemaska, where the community hosts summer gatherings.

“We’ll be getting more sophisticated drones for our area, including training,” added Jolly. “If we were able to report any fires to SOPFEU by drone, it certainly saves them the time and money rather than sending a plane. We’re adapting to the technology and able to monitor the weather a lot better.”

Drone technology is rapidly advancing to detect and suppress fires before they spread. These remotely piloted vehicles can serve as emergency first responders, picking up and dropping water autonomously, providing real-time images of inaccessible areas, and locating missing persons.

“Drones help us at forest fire hot spots where it’s not accessible and also help on fire investigations or search and rescue,” explained Blacksmith. “Drones have all this high technology, like heat sensors and infrared. Drones can carry items like life jackets and buoys that can be dropped and also speak with the person.”

Firefighters across the region are implementing a range of tools and strategies to better ensure community safety. A Cree Nation Fire Master Plan is being developed with Waswanay Consulting, identifying areas of heightened risk where communities are not yet prepared to intervene, such as airports.

“As communities expand rapidly, it affects fire protection, resources and training,” said former regional fire prevention officer George Cox, who recently transitioned to community public safety. “Sometimes a large fire was out of control and departments had to shut off operations because they were emptying out the water reservoir of the community.”

Chisasibi declared a state of emergency in June when lightning struck their water treatment plant while river levels were already critically low. While fires burned the week before and after the crisis, Chief Daisy House was thankful that none occurred when water was unavailable. 

Blacksmith said one fire remains active north of Chisasibi around the Rupert trapline but is expected to be extinguished by rain. Caused by lightning on June 10, it has burned slowly and isn’t considered a threat to the community.

The Fire Master Plan will detail how to access water resources during such a crisis through dry hydrants that can be installed near lakes or rivers. These non-pressurized tools involve permanently installed pipes, providing firefighters a reliable water source. 

Fire prevention officers from all Cree communities are participating in a unique mentorship program this summer with Ontario fire departments to learn about early detection systems, inspections and public education programs. Waskaganish fire investigator Tyler Diamond even assisted an active scene in St. Catharines, Ontario. 

“It builds their confidence to do the work in their community,” Cox said. “If we learned it all by ourselves it would probably take over a decade, so having this mentorship we can learn from people with 20 or 30 years of experience in the field.”

A similar program is planned for community fire chiefs, deputy fire chiefs, captains and lieutenants. Another initiative called Fire Smart is an online training program which offers guidelines for mitigating risk, such as having smoke detectors, fire extinguishers and two doors in bush cabins. 

A model cabin to demonstrate safety tips was featured at last fall’s Fire and Life Symposium in Mistissini. Another symposium will be in Wemindji this September, where the Cree Health Board, SOPFEU and police services are expected to attend.

urn:contentItem:6GCX-77V3-RXJN-800F-00000-00Closing of the First Tranche Private Placement for $179,550.002025-07-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:54ZLexisNexisClosing of the First Tranche Private Placement for $179,550.00

BOREAL GOLD INC ("BGLD-Z") - Closing of the First Tranche Private Placement for $179,550.00

Boreal Gold Announces the Closing of the First Tranche Private Placement for $179,550.00

Boreal Gold Inc (the "Issuer") has closed the first tranche financing of $179,550.00 of a non-brokered private placement announced on July 14, 2025. The closing is comprised of 598,500 Flow Through Units at a price of $0.30 per Flow-Through Unit representing proceeds of $179,550.00 for an aggregate total raised of $179,550.

The Offering is subject to certain conditions including, but not limited to, the receipt of all necessary regulatory approvals. The securities issued are subject to a four-month statutory hold period in Canada ending on December 1, 2025.

The Units consist of, and separate immediately upon closing into, one common share of the Issuer (each, a "Common Share") and one common share purchase warrant (each, a "Warrant"), each entitling the holder to purchase one Common Share at an exercise price of $0.30 per Warrant for a period of twenty-four (24) months following the date of issuance. The Flow-Through Shares shall consist of one Common Share, to be issued as a "flow-through share" (the "Flow-Through Shares") within the meaning of the Income Tax Act (Canada).

Use of Proceeds

Boreal Gold intends to use the proceeds from this financing to perform ground geophysical surveys over the western portion of the Fay Lake grid (not previously covered) as well as the north eastern portion of the Fay Lake grid that will be cut and surveyed to follow the strike extension of the Sunrise conductor to the eastern shore of Fay Lake. Drill testing of designed targets will follow up confirmation of Airborne conductors by ground geophysics on the Fay Lake property subject to a successful financing and direct consultation with Kiciwapa Cree Nation. Also planned is detailed mapping, prospecting, sampling and line cutting on the Fay Lake Property on a small portion of the Redwin volcanogenic massive sulphide horizon that remains unmapped but contains conductors.

Separate to the VMS exploration at Fay Lake above, gold exploration through mapping and prospecting of the western portion of the Puffy Lake Mine style gold mineralization trend, east of the Railroad. Approximately 10-line kilometers is planned on this trend where samples assayed up to 14.33 g/t Au, to evaluate its on strike continuity. The gold potential at Koscielny Lake located at the eastern end of the property south of the Puffy Lake Gold Mine will also be assessed. Here mineralization contained values of up to 11.81 g/t Au (0.38 oz/ton Au) over one meter (J. Pearson, Sept. 4, 2024, National Instrument 43-101 Fay Lake technical report).

North Star

Planned Program

Line cutting and refurbishing old Grids

Refurbish and recut the Grid from South of the North Star deposit on Line 46 N to Line 59 N between Baselines 46 E and Tie Line 59 E for both mapping and drilling purposes. This portion of the grid is almost 25 years old and overgrown to obliterated as it was cut a few years (12) after a forest fire.

Geological Mapping, Prospecting and Sampling

The Grids from Lines 59+50 N south to L 46 N will require geological remapping and detailed sampling to bring it up to the standard and detail of the northern grids that cover the Gold Rock and Richard Veins, with special emphasis on the section in between the North Star and Gold Rock deposits.

Drilling

Selective infill drilling, as well as down plunge drilling on the Gold Rock Vein with a view of completing a resource estimate and NI 43-101 compliant technical report (never undertaken). Ultimately the plan is to drill off enough tonnes that the combined resource of the North Star and Gold Rock Vein Structures, with sufficient grade, will warrant to bring it to a prefeasibility study. Even if successful on the first pass, this objective will require a few additional drill programs.

Melgurd Lake

On the Melgurd Lake property, following up detailed analysis of Airborne Geophysical conductors on strike with the Shotts Lake deposit and the encouragement found in the felsic volcanic package with VMS style alteration in the 2023-2024 field work, further work is planned to ground truth these conductors. Detailed mapping, prospecting, sampling and line cutting will be carried out over these conductors on the Keep Lake grid with follow up reports. Funds will also be used for corporate purposes.

Qualified Person

Stephen L. Masson, M.Sc., P.Geo. is the "Qualified Person" as defined by NI 43-101 Standards of Disclosure for Mineral Projects for these properties, has reviewed and approved the technical disclosure contained in this news release.

Boreal Gold Inc is a Canadian junior mineral exploration company with a specific focus on mineral properties in northwest Manitoba and northeast Saskatchewan, Canada. All of the Issuer's properties are currently at the exploration stage. The Issuer has assembled a portfolio of base metal and precious metal prospects in strategic locations in the Provinces of Manitoba and Saskatchewan.

What can you do to protect yourself?2025-07-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:54ZLexisNexisNEWS/GTAPg. 1Toronto is experiencing high risk air quality due to wildfire smoke. What can you do to protect yourself?Asma Sahebzada

Wildfire smoke from the Prairies is spreading to Toronto, causing hazy skies and potentially health hazardous air quality.

According to the province, downtown Toronto is experiencing high risk (level 7 out of 10) air quality on Thursday as wildfires burn in parts of the country including Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta.

As smoke drifts into southern Ontario, Environment Canada is asking people to limit the time they spend outside because, as smoke levels rise, so do associated health risks.

Some Toronto residents have reported hazy conditions with the air smelling like a forest fire, however, experts are only mildly concerned with the smoke.

Here's what you need to know about Toronto's air and how to protect yourself.

What is Toronto's air quality like this week?

Environment Canada's forecast is calling for smoke to drift from forest fires devastating the Prairies to Southern Ontario.

The wildfire smoke will cause poor air quality and reduced visibility on Thursday, changing over short distances and considerably from hour to hour, according to the government agency.

Early Thursday morning, Toronto had some of the worst air quality in the world that was high risk to health, but conditions are expected to clear up by the evening when air quality is projected to drop to a moderate level before a low risk of 3 in the night.

Skies are expected to improve from north to south.

This comes as Toronto experienced a week of scorching heat and humidity, but with Thursday arrived some relief from the hot weather as temperatures dipped to a pleasant high of 23 C and low of 14 C.

Should I be worried about the air quality in Toronto?

Air quality throughout the province is being affected by smoke from the wildfires but "it's not the same level that we were seeing almost exactly two years ago in 2023, early June, when the skies were very dark and we were having record levels of air pollution," said Rebecca Saari, a University of Waterloo associate professor who researches air pollution and it's health impacts.

"Part of the reason is that we don't have the same fires in Quebec, that were also joining with the western fires. That's what made 2023 so bad, but right now, it's just fires mainly to the west of the province and some in the northwest that we're contending with."

Saari said as it's a moderate risk in Toronto, those who are not vulnerable to the effects of the smoke can continue to go outside and breathe the air but those who are sensitive to polluted air should steer clear of the outdoors and consider rescheduling vigorous outdoor activities, especially if they're having symptoms.

For healthy adults, Saari said "there's no need to panic. Their risk is moderate. It's not a major acute concern," but she noted that the situation may change rapidly depending on how the fire evolves, if new fires develop and if wind patterns change. However, she does note that the more days with moderate levels of bad air can lead to higher exposure over the year and potentially risk health.

Who is most at risk from polluted air from wildfire smoke?

Sensitive groups most at risk of wildfire smoke air pollution include seniors, children, pregnant women, people with chronic diseases such as asthma and underlying health conditions such as heart and lung diseases.

Common symptoms caused by inhalation of smoky air include irritation of the eyes, nose, throat or lungs and for people who have pre-existing chronic conditions, the exposure of wildfire smoke may worsen their symptoms.

How can I protect myself from wildfire smoke?

The best way to protect yourself from breathing in bad air caused by smoke from wildfires is to stay indoors, said Saari, but for those who can't stay inside and are required to work outdoors, they are recommended to wear a well-fitting respirator-type mask such as an N95 or P100.

The masks are designed to reduce exposure to smoke by filtering out fine particulate matter. Wearing a mask and making sure you wear it properly prevents the particles from getting into the lungs and body.

"If you are outdoors for a prolonged period of time to do work, you also need to consider reducing the intensity of the work that you're doing and take breaks more frequently and ideally have a cleaner air shelter that you can go in and get some relief," said Angela Yao, a senior scientist with Environmental Health Services at the B.C. centre for Disease Control.

Yao points out that masks may become less effective if they build moisture through wearing it while exercising. Her advice is to shorten the length of time you spend outside and reduce the intensity of the outdoor activity.

Saari said staying indoors doesn't guarantee safety from the smoke if steps aren't taken to keep the smoke out. Those staying inside are advised to have windows and doors closed as much as possible and to keep indoor air clean, which could mean running a ventilation system and air conditioning with a well-functioning filter or by using a portable air cleaner.

For those who live in homes without a built-in ventilation system who rely on an open window to cool down, Yao said to avoid wildfire smoke by visiting a public space with cleaner, cooler air ventilation such as a shopping mall or library.

What to do before heading outside when there's poor air quality?

With Toronto finally getting a taste of summer this week , Saari and Yao both recommend checking the local air quality health index and to make it part of their daily routine.

"Sometimes wildfire smoke can linger for a long period of time, so it's crucial to know when it's a better time to go out," Yao said.

urn:contentItem:6GGG-B0D3-RRRK-W1JH-00000-00Over 90 percent of Newfoundland and Labrador's firefighters are volunteers, some even losing money to help contain province's wildfires2025-08-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:54ZLexisNexis6:30 PM ESTCBC RADIO ONEREBECCA ZANDBERGEN, FAITH FUNDALDuane AntleAIH2508086Over 90 percent of Newfoundland and Labrador's firefighters are volunteers, some even losing money to help contain province's wildfires

REBECCA ZANDBERGEN, FAITH FUNDAL (HOSTS):

[calypso]

FF: Three out-of-control wildfires are still raging in Newfoundland and Labrador. Hundreds of people have had to leave their homes, and Ottawa has sent in the Armed Forces and the Coast Guard to help. This week, Premier John Hogan called this summer a quote "unbelievable, historic, dry season." Leaving already exhausted firefighters to battle the fires without any reprieve from rain. Duane Antle is the president of the Newfoundland and Labrador Association for Fire Services, and the fire chief of Come By Chance, Newfoundland and Labrador. That's where we reached him.



RZ: Duane, what are you hearing from firefighters right now?

DUANE ANTLE: Right now, the firefighters who are on the front lines of the active fires, they're working really, really hard. They are tired. The work is dangerous. Some of them have taken their vacation time, some have just plain and simply given up their paycheques to be there, to support the communities. And, you know, they're praying for rain.

RZ: Giving up their paycheques because the majority of them are volunteers, right?

DA: Yeah, 90-plus per cent of the firefighters in our province are volunteers. That's correct.

RZ: What kind of strain is that for them to do this right now then?

DA: Well, it's a tremendous strain, not only financially, but if we think about it, you know, they're leaving their families, and their families are worried about them. If you really think about, when we go out to do our work, we can't do it without the support of our families. They're sitting at home. They're worrying about wildfires happening around their homes as well. But they're shouldering all that load themselves, while they allow us to go out and do our work. Now, I'll just clarify, I'm not on the front lines, but I'm talking to folks who are on the front lines every day.

RZ: How bad is this fire season in Newfoundland? Have you seen anything like this before in your career?

DA: No, never. You know, we've seen, I mean, we've always had a fire here and there, no doubt. Some years, less than others. But as an example, last year I think it was 58, and now we're almost to 200, and we're just a few shy of 200, so that's a big difference.

RZ: You mentioned some of the firefighters, the volunteer firefighters, have taken vacation, some have left, but others are staying on more than they normally would. What are you saying to them? Or who's talking to them and giving them the motivation to keep going back out?

DA: I think for the most part, you know, the public are really recognizing the, the contribution that they're making and the sacrifice that the firefighters and their families are making, and they're grateful for that. The government, our government, as well, has been very quick to recognize the hard work of the volunteers. And they are trying to bring in as many resources as they can to lessen the work on those volunteers.

RZ: Right. The army is there now helping, is it not, and the Coast Guard?

DA: Yes, that was announced today. And I also understand that Quebec and Ontario are going to be sending apparatus as well. So, hopefully, this will help get our folks back home to their families.

RZ: You know, the president of the Canadian Association of Fire Chiefs said today it's time for the federal government to have a National Forest Fire Coordination Agency, something like the U.S. Fire Administration. Do you think something like that would help?

DA: We have been lobbying for a federal fire secretariat now for a number of years. And having that agency in place, and it can be done rather quickly, and it's not a very expensive thing to do, that can be up and running. And it could do so many things for us inter-provincially. Getting equipment moved around. Getting crews coordinated and sent from province to province when they're needed. They could eliminate a lot of the paperwork. That fire secretariat is needed, and it's something that we really, really hope we can see put in place rather quickly.

RZ: How concerned are you for the future? Because we are seeing, it seems every year we hear more and more about wildfires. Nova Scotia is already doing something preemptively, telling people they can't go into the woods. And we're seeing your province also increasing dramatically the fines for people who are still having fires. We're talking $50,000 fine for the first offence at this point. I mean, if we look at what's happening, and do you worry what's next? What's in 2030?

DA: Well, of course, you know, things are not getting any better. And obviously, we have to recognize that climate change is real. Our summers are getting warmer and drier. And we used to have a joke in Come By Chance that you move here so you'd never get a sunburn. And now, it's almost like living in Florida. So, I know people are upset, you know, they can't go in the woods, they can't ride their ATV. You know what? That's a small sacrifice to make to keep a firefighter safe. Just a few nights ago, one of the crews fighting the Kingston Fire. The fire came around so quickly that they didn't even have time to pick up their equipment. They had to cut their lines, jump on the truck and run. That's how quick this happened. They came very close to losing their lives. I don't feel like we have the right to say it's OK to put people in harm's way to that extent so I can go for a ride on an ATV. It's not about keeping people out of the woods. It's about preventing another fire. Because you know what? We don't have enough to go around anymore. And the more that these folks have to go out and attend the fires, the more likely the risk of something bad happening to them. And we have to recognize that. And I think, you know, it's a small sacrifice.

RZ: I wonder, too. Do you think it's time to pay firefighters to have more fire services that have paid people working?

DA: Of course. I mean, it's inevitable. You know, the day of people giving up what they're giving up this week, you know, to fight that fire, like, those days are going to have to come to an end. And it's not because people don't want to do it, it is because people can't do it. You know, the financial strain on people is just going to be too much. And as calls increase, you know, people are needed more. Uh, you know, how long are, how long are the families going to be able to say, yeah, we can keep making sacrifices so we can do keep doing this?

RZ: Duane Antle, thank you very much for your time.

DA: And thank you for allowing me to share our story with you.

FF: Duane Antle is the president of the Newfoundland and Labrador Association for Fire Services. We reached him in Come By Chance, Newfoundland and Labrador.

urn:contentItem:6GFK-GH93-RRS5-Y2WD-00000-00Alberta's Longest Ballot byelection is a protest for what politicians' fear -- electoral reform2025-08-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:54ZLexisNexisOPINION/LETTERS-TO-THE-EDITORPg. 1Alberta's Longest Ballot byelection is a protest for what politicians' fear -- electoral reform

Long-ballot protest group signs up more in Alberta byelection featuring Poilievre, July 22

The Longest Ballot is not a prank, but a political protest designed to highlight our flawed electoral system and underscore the need for electoral reform. By using the loophole of non-resident candidacy, Pierre Poilievre is desperately circumventing our system of local representation. Fine for him to crawl through this loophole but when others follow suit he screams foul, even though he set the example.

As it stands, only the party in power can initiate electoral reform yet it is against their best interests to do so. The Liberals and Conservatives prefer the status quo which guarantees hyper-partisan infighting and wildly childish behaviour in parliament. They fear electoral reform. They support the travesty of a party forming a majority government while receiving a minority of popular votes cast. Electoral reform would be tantamount to enacting political anti-trust legislation. This is mirrored by the Conservative Party itself where Poilievre's minority of Tea Party style Conservatives have hijacked this once proud party.

Hyper-partisan politics is the hallmark of the disaster happening before our eyes to our southern neighbours. We should see this as a cautionary tale and strive for governments that include more voices. This can only happen through electoral reform. It will lead to coalition governments intent on getting things done. Coalition leads to Collaboration, Cooperation, Compromise and Consensus. This is what we should strive for. And be proud of, if our leaders would only find the courage.

David Ottenbrite, Cambridge, ON

David Olive reminds us that Canada is not broken

Trump could spell the death of Canadian auto production. Here's Plan B, July 31

Trump's tariffs are delivering a crushing blow to our steel industry. Here's how we turn that around, Aug. 2

In two columns last week, David Olive helped Canadians to think constructively in the face of U.S. President Donald Trump's tariff chaos. July 21 it was the auto industry. His option B urges us to consider a Canadian-owned and tariff-protected assembly industry, meeting defence and other public needs in the first instance, but also producing high-priority heavy equipment. I would add that, if federal and provincial governments are prepared to support multi-billion dollar battery-assembly plants, why are we leaving it to the Chinese to produce the small low-cost reliable electric cars and plug-in hybrids that our carbon reduction targets demand?

On Aug. 2, it was the steel industry. While supporting the anti-dumping and emergency relief measures already announced, he also has faith in the power of a rapid and rigorous buy-Canadian commitment for the steel that a "build, baby, build" Canada will need for, housing, infrastructure, and defence.

With facts at his fingertips, insightful analysis, and no fear of well-thought-out boldness, Olive reminds us that Canada is not broken. He reassures us that it is not economic ignorance or Oz-like fantasy to believe that Canada can and will thrive. Thanks David. Elbows Up!

Bill Winegard, Etobicoke

America's return to manufacturing will mean even more pollution

Months into his worldwide trade war, Donald Trump still appears resistant to learning how tariffs work, Aug. 5

As the GTA chokes on climate-change-worsened forest fire smoke, smoke we're perfectly willing to share with the Americans, let's consider that a "return to the golden age of American manufacturing" would mean ever more pollution. This is because the Trump MAGAs have zero interest in industrial laws that protect the environment, viewing them as nothing more than red tape. By outsourcing manufacturing, the U.S. has reduced industrial pollution here, emissions that the Americans would be happy to share with us. Thriving through Draconian tariffs is indeed what the Bard called "a tale told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing." That too many Albertans are willing to make noises about separation from the rest of Canada can only heighten Trump's fantasy of the dissolution of Canada and the acquisition of his "cherished" 51st state.

Ron Charach, Toronto

Canada is burning and Ford wants more road space for gas emitting automobiles'Most ridiculous decision': Doug Ford slams Ontario judge over bike lane decision, Aug. 6

We're in the midst of a smoke-filled climate change conundrum. Our Canadian forests are burning to a point where the smoke is soon to reach the shores of Europe. Meanwhile, Ontario Premier Doug Ford is in a spat with Ontario's judiciary, as he continues in his attempt to remove bike lanes in Toronto, so there'll be more road space for greenhouse gas-emitting automobiles. It's time for us air-breathing constituents to stand up and be counted.

Jack Drury, Toronto

Two quick fixes Republicans can implement to fight global warming forest firesManitoba's Wab Kinew accuses group of Republicans of pitching 'timber tantrum' over wildfire smoke, Aug. 6

Rather than create noise on social media with unsubstantiated blaming of fire management practices in Canada, GOP lawmakers can quickly and easily act on a couple of quick solutions to the epidemic of climate change. These would include sending more firefighting help where needed and immediately stopping the burning of coal, oil and gas.

Jack Bergmans, Toronto

A Doug Ford tunnel dream?'It's a vision and it works': Doug Ford offers new details on his plan for a Hwy. 401 tunnel, Aug. 6

Premier Doug Ford is a brave man to propose a three-level tunnel that's "never been done in the world" when Metrolinx can't finish the Eglington Crosstown or get the Finch LRT, which is all above ground, running. Is this a fantasy or just loose political talk?

Michael Levin, Toronto

Tunnel vision will bankrupt the province

Do people want a tunnel under the 401? Absolutely not! This is nothing but a colossal gift to Premier Doug Ford's construction friends and will almost certainly bankrupt the province. Instead of trying to use highway 407, which a previous Conservative government sold to private interests, the Ford government wants to waste our tax dollars on the 401 tunnel. I was in Windsor in July for my mother's 100th birthday and was shocked to find no one in my Windsor family knew anything about the tunnel plan. Windsor pays provincial taxes too, so why are they unaware of this huge government line item that will not help anyone in the province except GTA commuters?

Gord Deane, Mississauga

Tunnel cost estimates are laughable

The cost estimate for the proposed tunnel under highway 401 of $250 million to $1.5 billion per kilometre actually made me laugh out loud. Subway construction currently costs $700 million per kilometre for single level tunnels. The idea that we can build a much more complex triple level tunnel for anything less than double that is preposterous. If we are going to pursue this dreadful waste of money, at least let us go into the project with a realistic estimate of the cost.

urn:contentItem:6FS5-XP63-RRXX-S4C8-00000-00Fleeing C.B.N. fire was like 'the gates of hell opened,' Adam's Cove resident says2025-05-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:45:54ZLexisNexisFleeing C.B.N. fire was like 'the gates of hell opened,' Adam's Cove resident says

Sitting in the safety of the Salem Community Centre in Small Point, N.L., Richard Hayward of Adam's Cove compares fleeing his home to fleeing from hell.

"You see the whole community on fire right around you ... It's the gates of hell opened up," Hayward told Radio-Canada on Thursday.

"Within 10 minutes, I see the fire coming. Coming down, and the rise and the blazes, I'd say it was a couple hundred feet high."

Hayward was one of many residents in the town of Small Point-Broad Cove-Blackhead-Adam's Cove running from an out of control wildfire.

The fire was deemed contained on Thursday afternoon, as crews dealt with remaining hot spots. The fire burned as large as about 600 hectares.

The town has been under a state of emergency since Wednesday night. More than 20 buildings have been damaged or destroyed, the provincial government said on Thursday, including at least 12 homes.

Hayward's home still stands, he said, but his shed was lost.

"It came right to the road to my place and went right around my boundary line. Good thing I had my grass cut low, that's what the firefighter said. That's what saved my place," he said.

Scott Penney lives down the road from Hayward. He says he smelled smoke in his home on Wednesday afternoon and quickly evacuated with his family.

"By the time I got up to the end of the track to see [about] my neighbours and get them, all was engulfed. My front yard, my neighbours house in front of me, that was all gone," Penney said.

"Our town of Adam's Cove is gone."

Penney said he hopes insurance companies can respond to the damage quickly, but rebuilding will be a challenging process.

"We've got a population of 52 people, and now we got seniors with their house gone. How are they going to rebuild?"

Wildfire evacuation earlier than past years

The evacuation isn't the first of its kind in Newfoundland and Labrador, but could be among the earliest in recent history.

Newfoundland's forest fire season typically runs from the end of April to the end of September. In Labrador it's around mid-May to the end of September.

Last year, Labrador communities dealt with the same large-scale evacuation because of wildfires. Churchill Falls was evacuated on June 19, and Labrador City did the same just weeks later.

In 2022, large-scale forest fires in the Bay d'Espoir area prompted a state of emergency that lasted nearly a week that August.

Newfoundland and Labrador's active wildfire dashboard, which tracks the size and status of fires, reported 96 in 2024. 

As of Thursday, there have been 58 reported wildfires so far in 2025.

"I'm very concerned," Jeff Motty, provincial forest fire duty officer, told CBC's Here & Now on Thursday, adding parts of the province are abnormally dry for this time of year.

"Here we are, May 8, with 607 hectares [burned] on the books already. I just kind of look at every fire season as different, and I'm hopeful, you know, the rain's going to come."
